001package io.github.ai4ci.abm.riskmodel;
002
003import java.io.Serializable;
004import java.util.Arrays;
005
006import org.immutables.value.Value;
007
008import io.github.ai4ci.functions.KernelFunction;
009
010/**
011 * A convolution kernel or filter. This is an integer time based filter.
012 */
013@Value.Immutable
014public interface ConvolutionFilter extends Serializable {
015
016        // N.B. There is overlap between this and delay distributions.
017
018        /**
019         * Create an empty ConvolutionFilter instance with zero offset and an empty
020         * kernel density array. This filter will effectively have no effect when
021         * applied in a convolution operation, as it contains no density values to
022         * contribute to the output.
023         *
024         * @return a new ConvolutionFilter instance with zero offset and an empty
025         *         kernel density array
026         */
027        public static ConvolutionFilter empty() {
028                return ImmutableConvolutionFilter.builder().setOffset(0)
029                                .setDensity(new double[0]).build();
030        }
031
032        /**
033         * Create a ConvolutionFilter instance from the given offset and kernel
034         * density values. The offset indicates the index of the zero point in the
035         * values array, where positive values mean that the kernel is two-sided,
036         * zero means only left-sided, and negative values are allowed but may not
037         * make particular sense. The kernel density values are ordered from most
038         * recent (potentially future) to oldest (past) data point.
039         *
040         * @param offset: index of zero point in values. positive values mean that
041         *                the kernel is 2 sided. zero means only left sided.
042         *                negatives don't make particular sense but should work
043         *                consistently
044         * @param values: kernel density values, ordered from most recent
045         *                (potentially future) to oldest (past) data point
046         * @return a new ConvolutionFilter instance with the specified offset and
047         *         kernel density values
048         */
049        public static ConvolutionFilter from(int offset, double... values) {
050                return ImmutableConvolutionFilter.builder().setOffset(offset)
051                                .setDensity(values).build();
052        }
053
054        /**
055         * Create a ConvolutionFilter instance from the given KernelFunction. The
056         * offset will be set to the negative of the floor of the minimum value of
057         * the KernelFunction, and the kernel density values will be obtained from
058         * the values of the KernelFunction. The kernel density values are ordered
059         * from most recent (potentially future) to oldest (past) data point, and the
060         * offset indicates the index of the zero point in this array, where positive
061         * values mean that the kernel is two-sided, zero means only left-sided, and
062         * negative values are allowed but may not make particular sense.
063         *
064         * @param kfn the KernelFunction from which to create the ConvolutionFilter
065         *            instance. The offset will be set to the negative of the floor
066         *            of the minimum value of the KernelFunction, and the kernel
067         *            density values will be obtained from the values of the
068         *            KernelFunction.
069         * @return a new ConvolutionFilter instance created from the given
070         *         KernelFunction, where the offset is set to the negative of the
071         *         floor of the minimum value of the KernelFunction and the kernel
072         *         density values are obtained from the values of the KernelFunction
073         */
074        static ConvolutionFilter from(KernelFunction kfn) {
075                return ImmutableConvolutionFilter.builder()
076                                .setOffset(-(int) Math.floor(kfn.getMinimum()))
077                                .setDensity(kfn.values()).build();
078        }
079
080        /**
081         * Create a ConvolutionFilter instance representing a square kernel with the
082         * specified offset and length. The kernel density values will be set to 1.0
083         * for all entries, indicating equal weighting for each data point within the
084         * kernel. The offset indicates the index of the zero point in the values
085         * array, where positive values mean that the kernel is two-sided, zero means
086         * only left-sided, and negative values are allowed but may not make
087         * particular sense. The kernel density values are ordered from most recent
088         * (potentially future) to oldest (past) data point.
089         *
090         * @param offset index of zero point in values. positive values mean that the
091         * @param length the length of the square kernel, which determines the number
092         *               of data points that will be included in the kernel density
093         *               array. The kernel density values will be set to 1.0 for all
094         *               entries, indicating equal weighting for each data point
095         *               within the kernel.
096         * @return a new ConvolutionFilter instance representing a square kernel with
097         *         the specified offset and length, where the kernel density values
098         *         are set to 1.0 for all entries
099         */
100        public static ConvolutionFilter square(int offset, int length) {
101                var tmp = new double[length];
102                Arrays.fill(tmp, 1.0);
103                return ImmutableConvolutionFilter.builder().setOffset(offset)
104                                .setDensity(tmp).build();
105        }
106
107        /**
108         * Kernel values, offset as required, compared to a convolution this is in
109         * reverse order. The first value in this array is applied to the most recent
110         * data point, which may be in the future (prospective).
111         *
112         * @return the kernel density values, ordered from most recent (potentially
113         *         future) to oldest (past) data point
114         */
115        double[] getDensity();
116
117        /**
118         * get the kernel density value relevant to a point offset from now positive
119         * values of the offset are in the past, negative values relate to future
120         * data the full range of data is from [
121         * -prospectiveSize(),retrospectiveSize() )
122         *
123         * @param offset the offset from the current point in time for which to
124         *               retrieve the kernel
125         * @return the kernel density value relevant to a point offset from now, but
126         *         return zero if the offset is in the future
127         */
128        default double getDensity(int offset) {
129                var index = offset + this.getOffset();
130                if (index < 0 || index >= this.getDensity().length) return 0;
131                return this.getDensity()[index];
132        }
133
134        /**
135         * index of zero point in values. positive values mean that the kernel is 2
136         * sided. zero means only left sided. negatives don't make particular sense
137         * but should work consistently
138         *
139         * @return the index of the zero point in the kernel density values array,
140         *         where positive values indicate a two-sided kernel, zero indicates
141         *         a left-sided kernel, and negative values are allowed but may not
142         *         make particular sense
143         */
144        int getOffset();
145
146        /**
147         * get the kernel density value relevant to a point offset from now, but
148         * return zero if the offset is in the future
149         *
150         * @return how far does this kernel extend in the future (inclusive)?
151         */
152        default int prospectiveSize() {
153                return this.getOffset();
154        }
155
156        /**
157         * get the kernel density value relevant to a point offset from now, but
158         * return zero if the offset is in the future
159         *
160         * @return how far in the past does this kernel extend (exclusive)?
161         */
162        default int retrospectiveSize() {
163                return this.size() - this.getOffset();
164        }
165
166        /**
167         * Scale the kernel density values by a given factor, returning a new
168         * ConvolutionFilter instance with the same offset and scaled density values.
169         *
170         * @param factor the factor by which to scale the kernel density values
171         * @return a new ConvolutionFilter instance with the same offset and scaled
172         *         density values
173         */
174        default ConvolutionFilter scale(double factor) {
175                return ImmutableConvolutionFilter.builder().from(this)
176                                .setDensity(
177                                                Arrays.stream(this.getDensity()).map(d -> d * factor)
178                                                                .toArray()
179                                ).build();
180        }
181
182        /**
183         * get the total size of the kernel density array. The kernel density array
184         * is ordered from most recent (potentially future) to oldest (past) data
185         * point, and the offset indicates the index of the zero point in this array.
186         * The full range of data is from [ -prospectiveSize(), retrospectiveSize()
187         * ).
188         *
189         * @return the total size of the kernel density array
190         */
191        default int size() {
192                return this.getDensity().length;
193        }
194}
